MIA-001.title: Trust Calibration for AI Agents
sub_questions: What specific calibration capabilities do AI agents need that don't exist today, and which gaps represent IP opportunities?
Which enterprise sectors will face EU AI Act compliance pressure first, and what are their calibration readiness levels?
How are competitors (IBM, Microsoft, Google) positioning their calibration offerings, and where are they leaving gaps?
What is the actual implementation cost and complexity for enterprises to adopt calibration infrastructure?
How can Ainary influence the 2027-2028 CEN/CENELEC standards to favor its calibration approach?

MIA-002.title: Hierarchical Knowledge Graphs: Unifying OpenClaw and Obsidian into a Compound Intelligence System
MIA-002.thesis: The compound intelligence advantage comes not from better models but from better memory architecture — specifically, tiered knowledge with trust-weighted retrieval that lets agents access the right knowledge at the right confidence level.
sub_questions: What are the current approaches to bridging personal knowledge bases with AI agent systems?
How do hierarchical/tiered knowledge architectures compare to flat retrieval (standard RAG)?
What is the state of the art in knowledge graph construction from unstructured notes?
How does trust-weighted retrieval (boosting verified knowledge over ephemeral notes) affect output quality?
What are the practical implementation patterns for Obsidian-to-agent pipelines?

MIA-003.title: Knowledge Compounding with AI: Obsidian + Agents — What Actually Works, and What You're Optimizing for a Consumer That Doesn't Exist
MIA-003.thesis: Most AI+PKM setups fail not because the technology is wrong, but because they optimize for retrieval in a system that needs generation. The compound effect only kicks in when knowledge flows back — when outputs update inputs. 95% of Obsidian+AI setups are write-only graveyards with a fancy search layer.
sub_questions: What is the actual usage rate of AI-augmented PKM tools? How many notes get retrieved vs. written and forgotten?
Which AI+Obsidian workflows produce measurable compound effects (knowledge building on knowledge)?
What distinguishes systems that compound from systems that just accumulate? Is there empirical evidence?
What is the 'imaginary consumer' problem — are PKM tool builders optimizing for a user that doesn't exist at scale?
What are the practical patterns that work: daily notes, MOCs, agent-written summaries, RAG over vault, tiered knowledge?
